video.title: Python for Data Science - Course for Beginners (Learn Python, Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib)
video.description:
This Python data science course will take you from knowing nothing about Python to coding and analyzing data with Python using tools like Pandas, NumPy, and Matplotlib.


💻 Code: https://github.com/datapublishings/Course-python-data-science

This is a hands-on course and you will practice everything you learn step-by-step. This course was created by Maxwell Armi. You can check out more of his data science videos on his YouTube channel here: https://www.youtube.com/c/AISciencesLearn

🎥 Learn more about Data Science with videos from freeCodeCamp's Data Science Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAblQe2CCWqV4Zy3LY01Z8aF1

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction to the Course and Outline
⌨️ (0:03:53) The Basics of Programming
⌨️ (1:11:35) Why Python
⌨️ (1:33:09) How to Install Anaconda and Python
⌨️ (1:37:25) How to Launch a Jupyter Notebook
⌨️ (1:46:28) How to Code in the iPython Shell
⌨️ (1:53:33) Variables and Operators in Python
⌨️ (2:27:45) Booleans and Comparisons in Python
⌨️ (2:55:37) Other Useful Python Functions
⌨️ (3:20:04) Control Flow in Python
⌨️ (5:11:52) Functions in Python
⌨️ (6:41:47) Modules in Python
⌨️ (7:30:04) Strings in Python
⌨️ (8:23:57) Other Important Python Data Structures: Lists, Tuples, Sets, and Dictionaries
⌨️ (9:36:10) The NumPy Python Data Science Library
⌨️ (11:04:12) The Pandas Python Data Science Python Library
⌨️ (12:01:31) The Matplotlib Python Data Science Library
⌨️ (12:09:00) Example Project: A COVID19 Trend Analysis Data Analysis Tool Built with Python Libraries

4:15:00
Easy simple logic for this Question 
'''
User will enter a floating point number let say 238.915. Your task
is to find out the integer portion before the point (in this case 238)
and then check if that integer portion is an even number or not?
'''
x = float(input("Enter a real number :"))
y = int(x//1)
if x < 0:
    y=y+1
    
print(y)
if(y%2==0):
    print("Number is Even")
else :
    print("Number is Odd")

topLevelComment.text:
L = [1, 4, 0, 3, 5, 7]
n = len(L)
def searchMinFromList(L, n):
    minValue = L[0]
    idx = 0
    counter = 1
    while counter < n:
        v = L[counter]
        if v <= minValue:
            minValue = v
            idx = counter
        counter = counter + 1
    return minValue, idx
searchMinFromList(L, n)

replies.author: Alisha Hocane
replies.text:
def sortList(L, n):
    L2 = []
    counter = 0
    idx2 = 0
    while counter < n:
        [minValue, idx] = searchMinFromList(L, n)
        L2.append(minValue)
        del L[idx]
        n = n - 1
        idx = idx + 1
    return L2

            L[i] = L[j]
            L[j] = temp
print(L)

replies.author: Patrick W. FitzGerald
replies.text:
I've had the same question in the past seeing as practice is key to building skills. I had a tough time finding *free* resources providing exercises *with* solutions to practice and learn the basics of Python, but I did find a few that you might want to check out (in addition to freeCodeCamp):

This free book which has many exercises at the end of each chapter: http://spronck.net/pythonbook/ It covers some more advanced topics as well, I found that going through about 2/3 of the book was enough to move on to more interesting data science-related projects. (note that it is a few years old so it does not include the handy feature of f-strings for printing formatted strings)

The Kaggle course on Python has many exercises and it is not too long so you can finish it in less than a couple days (though it is recommended to have a bit of coding experience already): https://www.kaggle.com/learn/python I've done a couple other Kaggle courses (pandas, SQL) and I feel that if you want a fast track to gaining enough skills to start tackling data science projects as quickly as possible just doing all their courses should give you a very good start.

For numpy, matplotlib and scipy: http://scipy-lectures.org/

And here are some other resources for practicing the basics:
http://www.practicepython.org/
https://exercism.io/tracks/python
https://runestone.academy/runestone/books/published/thinkcspy/index.html

Hope this helps, good luck!

topLevelComment.text:
L = [1,2,4,-5,7,9,3,2]
for j in range(len(L)):
    m = L[j]
    idx = j
    c = j
    for i in range (j,len(L)):
            if L[i] < m:
                m = L[i]
                idx = c
                c += 1
    
    tmp = L[j]

L = [3,6,-30,20,21,-49,29,-9,-24,-1,0,43,7,2,10,4,3,3,3]

    idx = j             #^
    for i in range(j,len(L)): # i begins from the start value of j from the j loop so it skips previous indexes

topLevelComment.author: Jayjay F
topLevelComment.text: At 9:26:19 when using a while loop and saying while true what are you referring to being as true ? You have no reference to a variable being true , does a return statement in the while loop render the loop to be false ?

replies.author: Jayjay F
replies.text: @Kashif Murtaza intresting explanation, thank you

replies.author: Kashif Murtaza
replies.text: @Jayjay F in this case you can think this way but return and break are not same. Return statement immediately returns the control to the caller of the function, however break gives control to the very first statement after the loop body.

replies.author: Jayjay F
replies.text: @Kashif Murtaza so the return statement acts as a break for the infinite loop, thanks that makes sense

replies.author: Kashif Murtaza
replies.text: Normally a while clause accepts a condition which is either true or false. As long as the condition stays true, iterations of the loop execute. If we write just True, rather than a condition, it means the loop will run forever, sometimes called infinite loop. In such cases, break statement is often used based on some condition to exit the loop. Also, return statement also helps if loop is inside some function.

replies.author: Rahul Dua
replies.text:
I haven't seen the video so not sure where they reference this but generally, plt is the alias for matplotlib. 
In Jupyter, you should use:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
First line of code imports the library for use, the second line will display graphs without having to explicitly call the plt.show() method
